thread.title: Colts scrape by Jaguars in OT
thread.title_full: Colts scrape by Jaguars in OT

title: Colts scrape by Jaguars in OT
text:
Colts scrape by Jacksonville with Matt Hasselbeck, 16-13, in OT Zak Keefer , zak.keefer@indystar.com 6:21 p.m. EDT October 4, 2015 Adam Vintaieri, Frank Gore and Joe Reitz discuss the Indianapolis Colts' win. Clark Wade / IndyStar.com Indianapolis Colts quarterback Matt Hasselbeck (8) passes a TD pass to tight end Coby Fleener (80) in the second quarter of their game. The Indianapolis Colts play the Jacksonville Jaguars Sunday, October 4, 2015, afternoon at Luca Oil Stadium. (Photo: Matt_Kryger/The_Star) 
While The Franchise watched from the sidelines for the first time in his career, clipboard in hand, tennis shoes on feet, the Indianapolis Colts tried to do something they haven’t done since 2011. 
That is: Win a game without Andrew Luck. 
They did, scraping by 16-13 in overtime over the hapless Jacksonville Jaguars . And they can thank Jason Myers for that. 
Myers might not have a seat on the Jags’ flight home, not after missing two field goals with a chance to seal the victory. And in reality, he missed three. Myers botched two tries from 53 yards in the waning seconds but the first was negated because the Colts called timeout just before the kick. 
He missed another from 49 yards in overtime. 
It was enough. Barely. Matt Hasselbeck, the Colts’ 40-year-old backup quarterback, engineered a six-play, 53-yard drive that was capped by a 27-yard field goal from Adam Vinatieri. It was the 25th game-winning field goal of Vinatieri’s gilded career. 
It wasn’t pretty — wasn’t even close. But the Colts got the two things they needed: A victory and some rest for Andrew Luck. 
It was a strange reality, the Matt Hasselbeck Era in Indianapolis. However long it lasts – could be a few weeks, could be one game – the 17-year veteran did what was asked of him Sunday. Hasselbeck won the football game. 
He didn’t win with style, or sizzle, or spectacle, the way Andrew Luck often wins football games, but in this predicament that hardly matters. The Colts wanted a win and wanted to get out of here, allowing their starting quarterback the rest he needs for that sore throwing shoulder. Indianapolis Colts kicker Adam Vinatieri (4) celebrates his 54-yard in the first quarter of their game.
